Introduction

Salmonella are gram-negative, facultative anaerobic bacilli from the Enterobacteriaceae family.  These bacteria are primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route, often via contaminated food or water.  Salmonella infections can present with a spectrum of disease ranging from asymptomatic colonization to severe systemic illness.  Clinically, salmonellosis can manifest as gastroenteritis or, less commonly, invasive forms such as enteric fever, which is typically associated with resource-limited regions.  The most common species associated with human infections are Salmonella enterica subspecies, which are further classified into serotypes (eg, Enteritidis, Typhi, Paratyphi).

Pathophysiology

After they are ingested, Salmonella bacteria adhere to and invade the epithelial cells of the small intestine, specifically in the ileum.  The bacteria travel in vacuoles from the apical to the basolateral end of the cell and invade the lamina propria.

  • Nontyphoidal serotypes are phagocytosed by neutrophils and macrophages in the lamina propria and Peyer patches (lymphoid aggregations in the small intestine submucosa), and they induce a massive cytokine-mediated inflammatory response that causes gastroenteritis (eg, watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, fever).  Enterotoxin production disrupts electrolyte transport in enterocytes and promotes secretion into the gastrointestinal lumen.  Histologically, nontyphoidal Salmonella infection is characterized by acute inflammation with a predominance of neutrophils and edema within the lamina propria and Peyer patches.
  • Invasive strains (eg, Salmonella Typhi and Salmonella Paratyphi), which cause enteric fever, penetrate beyond the intestinal lining due to specialized virulence factors (eg, Vi capsular antigen).  These virulence factors inhibit neutrophil recruitment, phagocytosis, and the macrophage-derived oxidative burst, allowing for unmitigated intraphagocytic replication and dissemination of bacteria through the lymphatic and reticuloendothelial systems, with potential progression to bacteremia.

The degree of local or systemic spread depends on the serotype, the host immune response, factors such as gastric acidity, and the presence of competing intestinal microbiota.

Risk factors

The risk for contracting salmonellosis is increased in certain populations and environments.  Major risk factors include:

  • Extremes of age:  Infants (age <1) and elderly individuals are at higher risk.
  • Immunocompromised status:  Patients with immunocompromising conditions (eg, HIV/AIDS, diabetes, malignancy) or prescribed immunosuppressive therapy (eg, chemotherapy, biologics) are more susceptible.
  • Gastric acidity:  Reduced gastric acid secretion (eg, proton pump inhibitor use) decreases Salmonella destruction in the stomach, increasing susceptibility for development of disease.
  • Exposure to contaminated sources:
    • Undercooked eggs and poultry (bacteria can contaminate the surface and interior of eggs and poultry during processing), meat, and dairy
    • Contact with reptiles, birds, or other exotic animals (more commonly associated with nontyphoidal serotypes)
  • International travel:  Travel to resource-limited regions with inadequate sanitation and in patients who do not obtain pretravel vaccination is more commonly associated with typhoidal serotypes.
  • Functional asplenia:  Patients with conditions such as sickle cell disease are more prone to infection with Salmonella species due to functional asplenia and impaired ability to opsonize encapsulated bacteria.

Clinical presentation

The clinical manifestations of salmonellosis vary according to the infecting serotype and host factors.  Common presentations include gastroenteritis, enteric fever, bacteremia, and focal infections.

Gastroenteritis

Salmonella gastroenteritis is the most common form of salmonellosis and is typically seen with nontyphoidal serotypes.  Patients have diarrhea (Â± blood or mucous), abdominal cramping, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever.  Symptoms typically appear within 6-72 hours after ingestion and resolve within a week in most immunocompetent patients.  Development of invasive disease is rare.

Enteric fever

This syndrome of severe illness is typically caused by S Typhi and S Paratyphi serotypes, more commonly seen in patients in or traveling to resource-limited regions.  The typical incubation period is 5-20 days following exposure.  Enteric fever is characterized by prolonged progressive fever due to bacteremia.  Patients have notable pulse-temperature dissociation with relative bradycardia for the degree of fever.  In the second week of illness, patients typically develop abdominal pain (initial diarrhea may transition to constipation) and rose spots on the trunk and abdomen (due to microemboli of bacteria to the skin).  As symptoms progress, many patients develop hepatosplenomegaly (HSM), gastrointestinal bleeding, and intestinal perforation due to necrosis of Peyer patches (

Bacteremia and focal infections

Bacteremia, particularly from enteric fever, may lead to metastatic infections, including endovascular infections (eg, mycotic aneurysms), osteomyelitis (particularly in patients with hemoglobinopathies), septic arthritis, and meningitis, particularly in patients who are immunocompromised.

Asymptomatic carrier state

Patients with Salmonella infections may continue to have asymptomatic carriage of the bacteria for weeks to months after symptom resolution.  Transmission to others is still possible in the asymptomatic carrier state.  Notably, antibiotic therapy for nontyphoidal cases can paradoxically prolong the time of asymptomatic carriage because normal nonpathogenic gut microbiota is disrupted.

Diagnosis

A presumptive diagnosis of salmonellosis is often based on clinical suspicion.  Laboratory confirmation (eg, with culture) may take several days, and treatment based on a presumptive clinical diagnosis may be necessary.

Microbiology

Salmonella bacteria are oxidase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods that, with the exception of S Typhi, characteristically produce hydrogen sulfide in culture (which differentiates Salmonella from Shigella species).

  • Stool culture can provide definitive diagnosis of Salmonella infections but may be negative by the time patients seek medical attention due to systemic illness.
  • Blood culture is particularly important in suspected enteric fever or systemic infections, although results may take several days and are positive in only 40%-80% of cases.
  • Bone marrow culture is the most sensitive test for diagnosing typhoidal Salmonella infections and may remain positive even after the patient has received antibiotics.  This test is often deferred due to its invasiveness.
  • Serologic testing has limited diagnostic utility and is not generally recommended.
  • Multiplex stool pathogen testing (nucleic acid amplification test) is highly sensitive and can detect many enteropathogens rapidly and simultaneously.  However, it may not distinguish between organisms causing symptomatic infection versus asymptomatic carriage.  Stool culture is still required to obtain an antibiotic resistance profile.

Laboratory and imaging evaluation

  • Complete blood count:  Leukocytosis (more common in children) or leukopenia (more common in adults) and anemia are seen with enteric fever.
  • Liver function testing:  This may be elevated in patients with enteric fever, indicating hepatic involvement.  Transaminases and alkaline phosphatase are often elevated.
  • Fecal leukocyte testing:  Salmonella causes inflammatory diarrhea, so fecal leukocytes are seen, likely in combination with red blood cells.
  • Imaging:  This is generally not necessary for uncomplicated gastroenteritis.  However, imaging studies (eg, right upper quadrant ultrasonography or CT) may be warranted in cases of suspected focal complications, such as splenic or hepatic abscesses or concern for intestinal perforation.

Management

Supportive care

  • As with any patient with diarrhea, rehydration and electrolyte management are critical, particularly in cases of severe diarrhea.
  • In practice, patients are initially managed as having undifferentiated acute infectious diarrhea.  Stool studies are often performed and help differentiate between Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC) and non-STEC pathogens (eg, Shigella, Salmonella).  However, these studies may take several days (
    figure 1
    ).

If salmonellosis is confirmed, management depends on the clinical presentation and patient risk factors.

Antibiotics

  • Nontyphoidal Salmonella:
    • Antibiotic therapy is not indicated in most cases of nontyphoidal disease due to paradoxical prolongation of asymptomatic carriage and potential for development of antibiotic resistance.
    • However, patients who are at high risk for complications (eg, invasive disease) should receive antibiotics.  Risk factors include age <1, immunocompromise, sickle cell disease, implanted prosthetic devices (eg, artificial heart valve, prosthetic joints), and severe disease requiring hospitalization.  Bloody diarrhea in nontyphoidal Salmonella infection is not by itself an indication for antibiotic therapy.
    • Common choices for antibiotic therapy include fluoroquinolones, third-generation cephalosporins (eg, ceftriaxone), and azithromycin.
  • Enteric fever (typhoidal Salmonella):
    • This requires treatment with antibiotics due to bacteremia and risk for severe complications (eg, organ dysfunction, sepsis).
    • Third-generation cephalosporins (eg, ceftriaxone) are the preferred parenteral therapy for patients who are hospitalized, although growing antibiotics resistance in certain regions and culture sensitivities may shape antibiotic selection.
  • Invasive infections (eg, osteomyelitis, mycotic aneurysm):
    • Systemic antibiotic therapy tailored should be tailored to susceptibilities.  Prolonged courses are sometimes required.
    • Depending on the location of focal infection, source control with surgical intervention (eg, joint irrigation and drainage for septic arthritis) may be warranted.

Complications

Untreated or inadequately treated salmonellosis can lead to complications, particularly in immunocompromised patients.  Major complications include:

  • Dehydration and electrolyte imbalance occur from profuse gastrointestinal losses due to diarrhea.
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding and intestinal perforation are possible, particularly in patients with enteric fever, in which Peyer patches undergo ulceration and necrosis.
  • Metastatic infections are due to additional areas of infection seeded from bacteremia during enteric fever (eg, osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, endocarditis, mycotic aneurysms).  Sickle cell disease increases the risk for osteomyelitis (eg, slower blood flow and bone microinfarction from intermittent sickling), with Salmonella being a common cause due to functional asplenia and increased bacterial translocation from occluded intestinal segments.
  • Reactive arthritis is a postinfectious sequelae of Salmonella infections, with inflammatory changes in multiple tissues, predominantly the joints, eyes, and genitourinary tract (

    ).  Reactive arthritis is associated with HLA-B27.
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome is more common with certain E coli or Shigella infections but is possible in patients with severe Salmonella infections (

    ).
  • Gallbladder malignancy (eg, cholangiocarcinoma) can occur due to colonization of the gallbladder by severe typhoidal Salmonella infections.

Prognosis

Prognosis is generally favorable for self-limited gastroenteritis in healthy individuals, with symptoms resolving within a week without intervention.  However, complications and higher morbidity rates are more likely in infants, elderly individuals, and immunocompromised populations.  Enteric fever requires prompt antibiotic therapy to reduce the risk for complications and mortality.

Differential diagnosis

Key differential diagnoses include other bacterial, viral, and parasitic infections.

Campylobacter gastroenteritis

Campylobacter gastroenteritis presents similarly to Salmonella gastroenteritis, with fever and diarrhea (Â± blood), and may have historical features in common such as exposure to contaminated foods (eg, raw/undercooked eggs and poultry).  Most patients with Campylobacter infections have self-limited symptoms that generally resolve in one week without antibiotics (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
).  Campylobacter infections may be clinically indistinguishable from nontyphoidal Salmonella gastroenteritis.  Patients with typhoidal Salmonella infections have additional HSM on examination, progressive fever with pulse-temperature dissociation, and clinical worsening in the absence of antibiotic administration.

Shigella gastroenteritis

Shigella gastroenteritis typically presents with very severe, often bloody diarrhea (due to inflammation and ulceration of colonic mucosal cells).  Patients may also have tenesmus.  Stool cultures or PCR testing are positive for Shigella (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
).

Enterohemorrhagic E coli (EHEC)

EHEC O157:H7 is an STEC that causes bloody diarrhea and carries a risk for hemolytic uremic syndrome due to production of Shiga toxin (inhibition of ribosomes and protein synthesis).  Patients with EHEC do not tend to have the progressive fever seen in patients with enteric fever due to Salmonella.  Stool culture isolation of E coli O157:H7 or detection of Shiga toxin on molecular testing/immunoassay confirms the diagnosis (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 6
).

Viral gastroenteritis (eg, norovirus)

Viral gastroenteritis is generally self-limited, characterized by nonbloody diarrhea, vomiting, and a lack of high fever.  Fecal leukocytes and red blood cells seen in inflammatory diarrhea of salmonellosis are not typically seen in viral gastroenteritis.

Malaria

In the appropriate epidemiologic setting, malaria should be considered in all returning travelers with a fever.  However, fevers tend to be paroxysmal, unlike the progressively increasing fever seen in enteric fever due to typhoidal Salmonella.  Diarrhea is not a prominent symptom with malarial infections, although abdominal pain and HSM can be seen in both conditions.  The diagnosis of malaria is made by thin and thick peripheral blood smear or rapid testing.

Summary

Salmonellosis (

), a significant cause of gastrointestinal illness worldwide, ranges from self-limited gastroenteritis to life-threatening invasive disease.  Key risk factors include exposure to contaminated food, water, or environments; immunocompromising conditions; and extremes of age.  Diagnosis relies heavily on the patient's history and clinical presentation because confirmatory tests such as stool or blood cultures may not provide results in a timely fashion.  Treatment is primarily supportive for nontyphoidal variants, with antibiotics reserved for high-risk cases or in patients with enteric fever.  Complications such as metastatic infection from bacteremia may require surgical management or long-term antibiotic therapy.
